snippet: Gov. Rick Scott, who recently endorsed a Medicaid expansion, said he had not changed so much as Florida’s economy and deficit changed, freeing him to spend money.
abstract: Florida's Republican governor, Rick Scott, has, in his third year in office, marched toward the political center, a necessity in a diverse swing state; he has flabbergasted and angered his Tea Party supporters by endorsing Medicaid expansion, key component of the Affordable Care Act; Democrats are as puzzled by the turnaround as Republicans; Scott says it is not he who has changed so much as Florida’s economy and deficit, freeing him to spend money.

byline.contributor: Christine Jordan Sexton contributed reporting from Tallahassee, Fla.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott, who recently endorsed a Medicaid expansion, said he had not changed so much as Florida’s economy and deficit changed, freeing him to spend money.

headline.seo: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida Perplexes With Shift to the Center
headline.main: Anger and Kudos as Florida Governor Tacks Left
headline.print_headline: Anger and Kudos as Florida Governor Tacks Left

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
